helm-chart-collator/playbooks/roles/inst.message: If it's allowed to be no more than 63 characters, then why we cut on 15th?

The sha is only a segment of the final version (which is completed on line 21). For example, a version might look like this (without the truncation):

  provisioner-3.0.0_source.ffc0607e10d59e4240e838af27fb821bce8f3653d340c7353df63653603b54f5

Everything before "source" has a variable length, which means that we just need to provide enough space for that string.

PS2 moves this truncation to L21, which guarantees that all names are shorter than 63 characters, but it has the side effect of having variable-length sha's.

zuul.d/manila-tempest-jobs.yaml.message:
we could consider rename rally jobs to '*-no-dhss' too, or move this one to '*-no-ss'. 
'dhss' and 'no-dhss' seems to be more readable for new contributors.

That's a good point.. I didn't look at the rally jobs, the "-no-ss" comes from a pre "dhss" era, where we used to call the driver modes "no-share-servers" mode, and "share-servers" mode. 

We could pick one format and stick to it, and cause less confusion.

driver_handles_share_servers is a weird term, because the negative is driver_does_not_handle_share_servers and not driver_handles_share_servers_false or no_driver_handles_share_servers.. so I'm a bit conflicted. 

On various occasions, the driver modes have been termed:

- multi-svm vs single-svm (coming from a NetApp world where SVM=Storage Virtual Machine)
- dhss=true, dhss=false
- ss, no-ss
- hard-multitenancy, soft-multitenancy

Each one sparks a different kind of debate. But, I'm really in favor of nailing it down and documenting it consistently.

Sorry wrong link and dialect

Also, IMO, for the sake of maintainability and readibility, I think this part could be split and more commented. Bitwises operations are not really human readable and more details could help future maintainers to deep dive in this code.

By example by transposing with the given appendix

In your commit message you said that "This method is practically the reverse of get_ipv6_addr_by_EUI64()..." and and seeing that the appendix-A speak define how 
to create a modified EUI-64 format interface identifiers I wondering if we should you `eui64_unix_expanded` in place of `mac_unix_expanded` that is defined as a EUI48 strategy [1].

[1] https://github.com/netaddr/netaddr/blob/master/netaddr/strategy/eui48.py#L79
s/I wondering if we should you/I wondering if we should use/

There's a bit of a mess here.

Technically get_ipv6_addr_by_EUI64() takes anything that can be parsed into an EUI, but its docstring says you should pass an 48 bit mac to it.

But code search tells me everybody passes mac addresses to it:

http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=get_ipv6_addr_by_EUI64&i=nope&files=&repos=

On one hand there's the generic handling of any kind of EUI (no matter how many bits it is).

But then the use of 48 bit mac addresses is pervasive in neutron, while I personally don't know a single place in the code base where we actually use 64 bit EUIs (other than temporary values in rfc-mandated conversions).

We could also change and rename this method to get_EUI64_by_ipv6(), but then we'd leave half the work to our users (figuring out which two bytes need to be dropped).

I think most users expect a 48 bit mac returned here, therefore I think the least surprise is better.

Thanks for your interesting response :)

Make sense, so I'm ok to continue with the current PS.

It might mean that you'd have to do a GET default-types before you could make the call, but it would look like the other DELETE calls we currently have.

In this format, the call could fail with a 404 if the type_id isn't specified correctly, so maybe simply

  DELETE /v3/{project_id}/default-types

if you want to preserve the no-fail behavior.

Same as in the previous comment, it would have to be 

   /v3/{project_id}/default-type

How about:

  GET /v3/{project-id}/default-types

and we could handle the admin use case with '?all-tenants=1' like we do for volumes.  It would probably make sense to also allow the project_id filter if an admin is interested in some particular project (I believe the project_id in the URL path is the project of the caller?)

The response could be the same, without all-tenants=1 you'd get a list of size 1.

Using /v3/{project-id}/default-types?all-tenants=1 clashes with the recommended REST API resource naming... When we provide the project-id in the URL it means that we want the default-types for a specific project (which can have only 1), and passing parameter to pass a parameter to ignore the previous project-id parameter is not good practice.

If you don't like the current proposal and want to pass the project-id in the URL we would need to have 2 formats:

  GET /v3/{project-id}/default-type

and

  GET /v3/default-types

Which seems convoluted and non-intuitive.

And if we don't change this but change PUT/DELETE, then we end with different URLs for PUT/DELETE and GET, which I would prefer to avoid, and is why I chose the formats written in the current spec, to be consistent.

It looks like we're going to have a new mv this cycle that will display both type name and type id in the volume detail response because sometimes you need one, and sometimes the other.  I wonder if it would be worth including both here?
I'm going to withdraw this as a dumb suggestion.  The response to GET /v3/{project_id}/types/default gives all the information a normal user is interested in.

that is,

- Existing project id: Return null as the type_id

Just want to be clear on the response codes.
success: 202 or 204 with no body, or 200 and a body?
failure: volume_type doesn't exist or not accessible to project_id -- return 400?
failure: project_id doesn't exist -- return 404?
Any reason why volume_type doesn't exist has 400 instead of 404?

Yes, since the volume_type is specified in the request body, the problem is a malformed request body, so 400.  404 indicates that the resource described by the URL does not exist, which is not the case here.

You're right that we have 2 different 400s we might want to distinguish, that is:

(a) completely incorrect request body, e.g., {"garbage": true}
(b) syntactically correct request body, but indicated volume_type doesn't exist

You can return a different error message with the 400 to indicate which one has occurred.

Another possibility is to return a 409 for case (b) under the theory that the conflict could be resolved by creating (or making accessible to the project) the volume_type that's referred to in the request body.  That may be the best solution here.  So in the failure scenarios, we have:

failure: malformed request body -> 400
failure: project_id doesn't exist -> 404
failure: good request body, but volume_type doesn't exist or is inaccessible -> 409

That looks good to me, depending on the response code, it's clear what the admin needs to do.

Don't forget that you need to decide on what the success response should be.

I think the traditional handling of this is:
- if the default-type for project_id is defined, return 204
- if the default-type for project_id is not defined, return 404 (whether the project_id exists or not)

That being said, most of our v3 DELETE calls (13 out of 18) return a 202, so I guess we could return a 202 for all calls ... is that what you have in mind?  But then the caller would have to follow up with a GET /v3/default-types/{project_id} to verify that the delete had been completed.  I think it would be better to just 404 right away.  I didn't look at all the calls, but DELETE /v3/{project_id}/volumes/{volume_id} returns a 404 if volume_id doesn't exist, so that call at least isn't using a 202 in the missing resource case.

We only have 1 call currently that returns 204 for a successful DELETE (it's /v3/{project_id}/messages/{message_id}).  The 4 others return a 200.  But since we have a precedent for returning 204, I'd personally prefer that.

This is a super-nit, but these are really 2 different API calls:

1. "Show default type (for a project)"
  GET /v3/default-types/{project_id}

2. "List default types"
  GET /v3/default-types

I'm only pointing this out because it may make sense to have different policies governing these.  (For example, an operator might want to make 1 admin_or_owner, but have 2 be admin_only.)

Since we'll have keystone available, we should do a negative test to make sure the project-id-validation is working on the PUT call:

* Admin gets an existing volume-type-id (either by list or creation)
* Admin makes the PUT /v3/default-types/{project_id} call using a non-existent project_id
* call returns 404 (or whatever we decide above)

What to use for the nonexistent project_id is an interesting question.  In the past, a project id wasn't required to be a UUID, so maybe a string like "i_am_not_a_project_id" would work.  On the other hand, if they must be UUIDs these days, we do want to use a UUID so that our request to keystone doesn't fail because of a syntax problem (we want to make sure the actual project lookup doesn't find anything and we're detecting that correctly).  So maybe an all-zero UUID?  Tempest may already have something for this in their keystone tests.

doc/source/install/index.rst.message:
To be honest, I don't entirely agree with this.
We explicitly say on L343 that we need to activate the virtualenv before running any playbook, that means that the ansible-playbook binary path in the virtualenv take over on the system ansible-playbook binary path.
To verify this, just install ansible system-wide, check the path of ansible-playbook, then create a virtualenv, activate it, install ansible with pip, and check the ansible-playbook binary path again.
Another proof is given by the change of the PATH environment variable, when activating the virtualenv the value is modified to include the virtualenv /bin directory as primary binary path.
Things that we could specify instead are to double-check that the virtualenv is active, that the path of ansible-playbook is the correct one in the virtualenv, and that PATH includes the bin dir inside the virtualenv.
Running the binary with full path should not be necessary, unless we do it without activating the virtualenv itself.

sed -re "|^#baseurl=http[s]*://mirror.centos.org/(centos|altarch)| ..."

wow, a one liner sent me down a half-hour rabbit hole :)

did you know

 $ echo "foo" | sed 's|\(foo\|bar\)|moo|'
 foo

doesn't work?!

If you read posix on it 

> Within the BRE and the replacement, the BRE delimiter itself can be used as a literal character if it is preceded by a backslash."

so by using "|" as the delimiter "\|" becomes a literal | in the expression and it doesn't match.  TIL

ergo this match doesn't work because both because it needs to quote the \( and \| (or switch to -E for) but there's the more subtle problem of the | match
Can't we just then replace *any* [a-z]+ string between the / and avoid comma drama?
probably; i think it works fine now and reads pretty clearly though

zuul.d/openvswitch.yaml.message: this is very weird to me. I believe we should instead change the zuul.d/openstack-loci build process to make sure we can pass a certain OVS_VERSION. If necessary we'll need to update LOCI itself to support that. This looks too hacky to me.

Reusing the same components make sense, but then we need to make things right in the first place: Use the same repo at image building of the ovs image and at the loci images. This means that if a change targets both LOCI image build and ovs build, it will lead to inconsistent results, because they will be built in parallel, not in serial, in gates.

We need to make sure things are properly built in parallel, by not leveraging the other image to hack things on top, but rather make things right in both images by leveraging the same packages.

On top of that the last two will have both the same tag, and the image name is not representative of what's in it.

Definitely voting negatively for this.

openstack-loci images today do not use source build binaries for OVS it rather rely on ubuntu distributed debian (2.5.+) for xenial. so tried to have a separate series of build which is based on source built packages.

using same version of OVS in both nova and neutron components along with openvswitch containers is important, so building them together may make more sense?

openstackhelm/neutron:ocata-ovs-2.10.1-debian
openstackhelm/nova:ocata-ovs-2.10.1-debian

Not sure this makes sense. The deploy is really done after the upgrade playbook runs successfully. The problem with doing this here is that this state handler could fail at some point (e.g. due to comms loss), but the upgrade may actually complete in the subcloud. In that case, another pass through the state machine will not update the deploy_status because the upgrade will already be complete.

After assessing various failure scenarios, this implementation is the safest, most reliable and resources efficient (no unnecessary sysinv/keystone requests). Will create a finalize_completing method to update the subcloud deploy status which can be called in both cases.

So with this, admins would need to be aware that the number of allocations could grow a bit faster when these limits configured.
What if the back end doesn't have the capability to provide  yet one more share server -- e.g. it has hit some limit on the number of these that it can offer?

In this case, when creating a new share server, backend itself is going to deny the request (as it would happen even if these new limits were not implemented and manila tried to provide a new share server).
But a good option to the administrator in this case would be to set higher values to these share server limits or even set -1 (no limit), so manila woudn't request the creation of a new share server and would reuse the existent ones.
